Problem:
Consider a system defined by a complex function \\(z(t) = x(t) + iy(t)\\) governed by the equation \\(\\frac{dz}{dt} = pz + q\\), where p and q are complex constants. Examine the effect of an integral transformation \\(T(z) = \\int_0^t e^{st}z(s)ds\\) applied over time t, with s being a complex constant.

If \\(T(z)\\) is applied to the function \\(z(t)\\) and then allowed to evolve under the original differential equation without further intervention, will \\(z(T)\\) at some later time T be the same as if \\(z(t)\\) was directly evolved to time T under \\(\\frac{dz}{dt} = pz + q\\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\(T(z)\\) fundamentally alters the initial conditions of the system through integration, potentially modifying the system's trajectory over time. The evolution of this altered initial state under the original differential equation will not result in the same state at time T compared to evolution from the unmodified initial conditions.
